newsitem.title: FRANCE: Delors would be Jospin adviser not minister-source.
newsitem.headline: Delors would be Jospin adviser not minister-source.

text.p: Former European Commission president Jacques Delors could serve as a special adviser to Socialist leader Lionel Jospin if the well-placed left-wing opposition wins Sunday's parliamentary election but would not take a cabinet post, a source close to him said on Friday.

The left-wing Liberation daily, close to the Socialists, said Delors, a former Socialist finance minister in the 1980s, was favourite to take a superministry for foreign and European affairs if the left won.
Delors described the report as "journalists' speculation" and there was no immediate comment from the Socialist party.

A source close to Delors said he could play an important role, if asked, as an adviser to Jospin and a special envoy, for example in smoothing relations with Germany, without having to hold a ministerial post.
Delors, 71, has served as an elder statesman and moral reference for Jospin during the campaign, giving his blessing to the party's conditions for joining a single European currency.
Liberation said: "(President) Jacques Chirac could hardly refuse him, and he would have the advantage of being able to talk on an equal footing with German Chancellor Helmut Kohl."

But the source said taking a cabinet job "would not be coherent with everything he has done since December 1994", when he decided not to run for the presidency in 1995, citing his age and the difficulty of governing with a right-wing majority.
Chirac, a conservative Gaullist who won that election, criticised Delors' federalist approach to European integration during the campaign and has not consulted him since then.

Delors and Kohl are close friends and the former commission president is widely respected in Germany, where the prospect of an upset Socialist-Communist French election victory has been viewed with some alarm.

Delors headed the Brussels-based European executive for a decade from 1985 until the end of 1994, presiding over the completion of the single European market and playing a major role in drafting the 1991 Maastricht treaty on economic and monetary union.
Since 1995, he has concentrated his energy on a think-tank, Notre Europe (Our Europe), dedicated to research and policy proposals on European issues.
Liberation said other possible contenders for the foreign ministry were centre-left ex-prime minister Michel Rocard, a member of the European parliament, and former premier Laurent Fabius.
